Award.AwardTitle: Uncertainty in Models of Authority and Models of Matching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed work consists of two parts: The first part aims to enhance our understanding of the implications of stability of matching outcomes under incomplete information. There is a voluminous literature using matching models to analyze two-sided markets, including problems of matching students to schools, residents to hospitals and workers to firms. The commonly employed solution concept when analyzing matching problems is the core. The use of the core as a solution concept incorporates the stability of a proposed matching between workers and firms: if the proposed outcome is not in the core, we would expect the outcome to be upset by the pair that could jointly improve their circumstances. Matching typically assumes complete information: all parties know exactly what the consequences would be for any possible match. The assumption is crucial because for the standard problems to which these models are applied, participating agents care about the characteristics of their matched party. The PIs propose to extend previous work that defines pairwise stability in incomplete information environments. The main thrust of the proposed work in this area is to investigate how the techniques used can be modified to understand matching in many-to-one environments.

The research will provide a better understanding the conditions that assure that there are stable matching of workers to firms and the efficiency properties of such matching. Such an understanding will give insight about possible interventions that will ameliorate inefficiencies in matching problems. The complete information matching theory has had a significant impact on the design of the mechanisms used to assign student to schools and residents to hospitals. This research has the potential of improving the economic performance of these mechanisms.

In the second part of the proposal the PIs propose to formally model the process by which laws are, or are not, followed by the agents assumed to be subject to those laws. They suggest that some laws continue to be followed for some time, despite changes in the environment that affect agents' incentives to follow those laws, but then collapse quickly even though there seems to be
no dramatic change in the environment. The PIs propose to formalize models of this process of social change that are consistent with such behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have continued our exploration of the impact of signal manipulation in matching on the choice of costly assessment of sign??als.  With Larry Samuelson, we have made significant progress on the description of the benchmark model, where schools must decide which signals to use in assessing student quality, when these signals are costly.  We continue to work on this. We continue to work with Stephen Morris on questions concerning the sources of authority.

Separately, Mailath?s project with Larry Samuelson on ?The Wisdom of the Confused Crowd: Model Based Inference? (new title: ?Learning under Diverse World Views: Model-Based Inference?) was published in the American Economic Review (May 2020, 110: 1464-1501).  The goal of the project was to understand the effectiveness of information aggregation in prediction and related markets by examining information exchange between Bayesian agents whose inferences are based on different models of the underlying world. 

Mailath finished the project with Harold Cole, Dirk Kreuger, and Yena Park on ?Fragile Financial Coalitions? (new title: ?Coalition-Proof Risk-Sharing Under Frictions?). This project analyzes the efficient arrangement of ﬁnancial coalitions under incomplete enforcement.  The coalitions are endogenously formed to undertake consumption smoothing.  There is a friction in coalition formation, so that any attempt to form a coalition may fail.  The focus of the analysis is the impact on consumption smoothing of the possibility that groups of agents (typically the wealthier agents) have an incentive to deviate from the initial contract by forming a deviating coalition.  If it is easy to form a deviating coalition (there are few frictions), the resulting coalition incentive constraints preclude significant consumption smoothing, while significant frictions will allow significant consumption smoothing.  This work is currently under review at the American Economic Review.

Separately, Postlewaite continued his work on memorable goods. In previous work with Rong Hai and Dirk Krueger, Postlewaite introduced the notion of ?memorable goods? in an otherwise standard dynamic consumption macroeconomic model. Memorable goods consumption differs from nondurable goods consumption in that current memorable goods consumption may also impact future utility through the accumulation process of the stock of memory. In that model, households optimally choose a lumpy profile of memorable goods consumption even in a frictionless world. Using Consumer Expenditure Survey data, they then document levels and volatilities of different groups of consumption goods expenditures, as well as their expenditure patterns, and show what would seem anomalous volatility disappears. That work is written up in ?On the Welfare Cost of Consumption Fluctuations in the Presence of Memorable Goods?. The paper is now revise and resubmit at Quantitative Economics.

Postlewaite continues work with Richard McLean on robust mechanism design. They demonstrate how one can design auction mechanisms that substantially relax the assumptions of what is common knowledge among the participants. They are extending the analysis of an earlier paper, ?A Very Robust Auction Mechanism?.

Postlewaite, with David Schmeidler, published ?The Hurwicz Program, Past and Suggestions for the Future? if Social Design. Essays in Memory of Leonid Hurwicz, ed. Walter Trockel, Springer. This paper reviews and critiques the work by Leonid Hurwicz on implementation.

With Stephen Morris Postlewaite revised ?Observational Implications of Non-Exponential Discounting?. That paper is forthcoming in Revue Economique.

Postlewaite completed a paper with Gilboa, Samuelson and Schmeidler, ?What are Axiomatizations Good For?? that was published in Theory and Decision. This paper is a methodological treatise on the foundations of economic science.
